author: Staff Reporter
text:
K. Vijaya Bhaskar Raju, professor of Gitam University, on Wednesday, said that it had become more difficult to get an admission in the commerce stream than in the engineering stream.

Speaking at a career guidance conference organised by The Hindu In School and Gitam University at Sindhi Model Senior Secondary School, Mr. Raju noted that there were hundreds of engineering colleges across the State and hence it was a tad easier to get a seat for an engineering course than it was for commerce.

“Last year, in some engineering colleges in the State, the number of admissions was in single digit or two digits,” he added.

‘Look at facilities’

Mr. Raju said that students should take a look at the facilities available at the college, the affiliation and grading before deciding to study there.

“You should also remember that good communication skills are important for you to get a good job during placement,” he added.

G. Sanjana, a class X student of the school, said she planned to join the commerce stream and eventually pursue Master of Business Administration (MBA).

“I’m still thinking of other options too; so, these career guidance sessions should help me,” she added.

‘Focus on science’

N. Riddhi, a class X student of the school, noted that most of the career guidance programmes only focussed on the science stream and the opportunities available for it.

“We seldom see any focus on commerce,” she added.

Students from classes X, XI and XII participated in the career guidance programme.

Abdul Raheem, Principal of the school, also spoke at the event.

Importance

of good communication skills stressed by expert
title: ‘More competition for commerce seats in colleges’
